//           "Betty Ann Morris served in the United States Marine Corp for 3 1/2 years, became a flight attendant with TWA and later played a major role in the American Craft Movement working with leather and creating free form baskets. She has been a purveyor of antiques for the past 30 years and became a professional artist in 2003 after she took a plein air workshop in Newport, Rhode Island. For a time, Morris owned and operated her own studio and gallery in Newport but is now retired and living in Venice Florida. She continues to paint and enjoy life."

She has been a purveyor of antiques for the past 30 years and became a professional artist in 2003 after she took a plein air workshop in Newport, Rhode Island. For a time, Morris owned and operated her own studio and gallery in Newport but is now retired and living in Venice Florida. She continues to paint and enjoy life."

//     "description": "The root schema comprises the entire JSON document.",

//                 "information": "The term Anatolian rugs is used to describe rugs from an area of Asia minor and surrounding regions. Some of the oldest carpets in the world can be dated to this region. The intense colors and abstract designs, combined with traditional tribal symbols, makes them a favorite around the globe. Carpet weaving is a tradition that dates back to the earliest tribal cultures in the region.  Although there are a few exceptions, many Anatolian rugs use the symmetrical, or Ghiordes, knot. Most are made from all wool that is sourced from local sheep. You will sometimes see an unusual color in the rug because of a locally available plant dye. On a rare occasion, you can find an exotic fiber such as goat, bear, camel, or ox. As a group, the designs, colors, materials, and techniques used to create these masterpieces are as varied as the people themselves.\r\n",

//                 "information": "Costa Ricas Pura Vida attitude and the peoples appreciation of nature are a delight for visitors, as well as an inspiration for artists.  With a varied art history, the nations many styles reflect the different origins of its people and home to many respected artistic traditions.  Costa Rican art is a product of the blending of its three main communities:  the Indigenous, European, and African populations which have all contributed their culture and traditions.  These have now come together to create an elaborate range of artistic expression.  Costa Rican paintings do not seem to imitate the European or native styles, rather it is a combination of the styles.  Costa Ricans are best known for their unique expression of design.  As for inspiration, Costa Rica is an artists paradise with a plethora of interesting landscapes and breathtaking scenery.  In recent decades, several contemporary Costa Rican artists have gained international fame, and their contributions to the artistic world extended far beyond the countrys borders.\n",
